title: Create /bd-swarm-auto skill for fully autonomous backlog completion
description:
Separate skill from bd-swarm that runs autonomously until backlog is empty.

## Why Separate Skill
- Simpler invocation (no --auto flag)
- Self-resumable after /wipe (handoff says "Run /bd-swarm-auto")
- Dedicated system prompt optimized for autonomous decisions
- Claude-invokable via Skill tool

## Features
1. **Wave loop** - Process waves until `bd ready` empty
2. **Parallel worktree setup** - Create all worktrees + npm install
3. **Worker spawning** - Via TabzChrome API or direct tmux
4. **Monitor polling** - Every 2 min via tmuxplexer
5. **QA checkpoints** - Run tabz-manager between waves (parallel with merge/setup)
6. **Context monitoring** - At 70%, /wipe with handoff to continue
7. **Bug creation** - QA issues added to backlog automatically

## QA Checkpoint (between waves)
Run tabz-manager in parallel with merge/worktree setup:
- Start dev server
- Screenshot desktop/tablet/mobile
- Check console errors
- Create bug issues if problems found
- Bugs picked up in next wave

## Self-Recovery
After /wipe, handoff contains:
```markdown
## Auto-Swarm in Progress
Wave N processing. Run `/bd-swarm-auto` to continue.
```
Beads has full state - just resume.

## Files
- plugins/conductor/skills/bd-swarm-auto/bd-swarm-auto.md
- plugins/conductor/agents/tabz-qa.md (QA routine for tabz-manager)
close_reason: Created /bd-swarm-auto skill with full wave loop, worktree setup, worker spawning, monitoring, merge/cleanup, and context recovery support

title: Watcher: reuse low-context workers for follow-up tasks
description:
When a worker completes a task with low context usage (<50%), don't kill them. Instead:

1. Detect completion + check context % from tmuxplexer/state
2. If context < 50%, check `bd ready` for related unblocked issues
3. Send next task to same worker via tmux send-keys
4. Only kill when context >= 50% or no related tasks available

## Benefits
- Workers already have skills/plugins loaded
- CLAUDE.md and codebase understanding preserved
- Faster task completion (no cold start)
- More efficient token usage

## Related task detection
Could match by:
- Same component/area (inferred from file paths)
- Same type (feature, bug, task)
- Explicit `related_to` field in beads
- Priority order if no better match

## Implementation
Update watcher.md pipeline:
```
WORKER_DONE + context < 50%:
  â†’ Check bd ready for related tasks
  â†’ If found: send new task prompt
  â†’ If none: proceed to cleanup

WORKER_DONE + context >= 50%:
  â†’ Proceed to cleanup (worker is tired)
```

## Files
- plugins/conductor/agents/watcher.md
- plugins/conductor/commands/bd-swarm.md (document behavior)
close_reason: Worker reuse implemented in watcher.md

title: Conductor: poll tmuxplexer pane instead of watcher subagent
description:
## Current Problem
The watcher is a separate subagent that:
- Burns context on monitoring
- Detected stuck workers but didn't nudge properly
- Would incorrectly nudge workers waiting on AskUserQuestion

## Simpler Approach
Remove watcher subagent. Conductor monitors via background window in its own session.

### 1. Spawn tmuxplexer in background window
```bash
# TabzChrome windows start at 1
# Window 1: conductor/claude (main)
# Window 2: tmuxplexer --watcher (background monitor)

# Check if monitor window exists, create if not
if ! tmux list-windows -F '#{window_name}' | grep -q "^monitor$"; then
  tmux new-window -d -n "monitor" "tmuxplexer --watcher"
fi
```

User can click status bar to switch to monitor window if they want to see it.

### 2. Periodic pane capture (every ~2 min)
```bash
tmux capture-pane -t ":monitor" -p
```

Output shows per-worker: session name, status, context %, current tool

### 3. Decision logic
Parse tmuxplexer output:
- `awaiting_input` â†’ User question pending, don't nudge
- `processing` / `tool_use` â†’ Working, leave alone  
- `idle` + issue still open â†’ Check worker pane for details
- Issue closed â†’ Worker done, can cleanup

### 4. Drill down only when needed
```bash
# Only if worker looks stuck, capture their actual pane
tmux capture-pane -t <worker-session> -p -S -50
```

## Benefits
- No separate watcher subagent
- Background window in conductor's session (not cluttering user's view)
- User can switch to monitor window via status bar if curious
- Single pane capture = all worker statuses
- Conductor retains full context for decisions
close_reason: Replaced watcher subagent with tmuxplexer background window polling. Created monitor-workers.sh script, simplified bd-swarm.md from 700 to 290 lines, moved watcher reference material to references/monitoring.md, removed watcher.md agent.

title: Refactor conductor workflows into composable atomic commands
description:
## IMPORTANT: Create Backup First

Before refactoring, create a backup of the current conductor plugin state:
```bash
cp -r plugins/conductor plugins/conductor-backup-20260106
```

This ensures we can recover if the refactor breaks existing workflows.
design:
## Problem

Current `worker-done` skill is monolithic - all steps run together, hard to customize or swap implementations.

## Solution: Composable Commands

Each pipeline step becomes an atomic command in `plugins/conductor/commands/`:

### Proposed Atomic Commands

| Command | Purpose | Notes |
|---------|---------|-------|
| `/verify-build` | Run build, report errors | |
| `/run-tests` | Run tests if available | |
| `/code-review` | Opus review with auto-fix | Spawns conductor:code-reviewer agent |
| `/codex-review` | Codex review (read-only) | Runs `codex review --uncommitted`, cheaper |
| `/commit-changes` | Stage + commit with conventional format | |
| `/create-followups` | Analyze for follow-up issues | Important for research tasks |
| `/update-docs` | Check/update documentation | |
| `/close-issue` | Close beads issue | |

### Orchestrator Commands

`/worker-done` becomes an orchestrator that calls atomic commands:

```
/verify-build && /run-tests && /code-review && /commit-changes && /close-issue
```

### Example Compositions

```bash
# Standard completion
/verify-build && /run-tests && /code-review && /commit-changes && /close-issue

# Quick completion (skip review)
/verify-build && /commit-changes && /close-issue

# Codex review instead of Opus (cheaper, read-only)
/verify-build && /run-tests && /codex-review && /commit-changes && /close-issue

# Research task (needs followups)
/verify-build && /code-review && /commit-changes && /create-followups && /close-issue
```

## Codex Review Details

Codex CLI v0.77.0 has purpose-built `codex review` command:

```bash
codex review --uncommitted -C $WORKTREE
codex review --base main -C $WORKTREE
```

- Inherently read-only (no --sandbox needed)
- Cheaper than Opus (~$0.02 vs ~$0.15 per review)
- Has access to Tabz MCP and Beads MCP
- Output is natural language (needs parsing to JSON for conductor)

### Trade-offs: Opus vs Codex Review

| Aspect | Opus code-reviewer | Codex codex-review |
|--------|-------------------|--------------------|
| Auto-fix | Yes (Edit tools) | No (read-only) |
| Cost | Higher | Lower |
| Speed | Slower | Faster |
| MCP access | Via Claude | Native |
| Output | Structured JSON | Parse NL to JSON |

## File Structure After Refactor

```
plugins/conductor/
â”œâ”€â”€ commands/
â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ verify-build.md      # NEW atomic
â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ run-tests.md         # NEW atomic
â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ code-review.md       # NEW atomic (wraps agent)
â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ codex-review.md      # NEW atomic (runs codex CLI)
â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ commit-changes.md    # NEW atomic
â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ create-followups.md  # NEW atomic
â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ update-docs.md       # NEW atomic
â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ close-issue.md       # NEW atomic
â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ worker-done.md       # NEW orchestrator
â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ bd-swarm.md          # existing
â”‚   â””â”€â”€ ...
â”œâ”€â”€ skills/
â”‚   â””â”€â”€ worker-done/         # can remove after migration
â””â”€â”€ agents/
    â””â”€â”€ code-reviewer.md     # keep for /code-review to spawn
```

## Benefits

- **Customization**: Mix & match commands for different workflows
- **Testing**: Test single steps in isolation
- **Swap implementations**: Use `/codex-review` instead of `/code-review`
- **Recovery**: Resume from failed step instead of re-running everything
- **New workflows**: Compose existing commands instead of writing new skills
acceptance_criteria:
0. **BACKUP FIRST**: `cp -r plugins/conductor plugins/conductor-backup-$(date +%Y%m%d)`
1. Each atomic command works standalone
2. `/worker-done` orchestrator calls atomic commands in sequence
3. `/codex-review` runs Codex CLI and parses output to JSON
4. Commands can be composed in different orders
5. Existing bd-swarm workflow still functions
close_reason: Refactored conductor workflows into composable atomic commands

comments.author: marci
comments.text:
## New: .beads/PRIME.md Workflow Customization

Beads now supports workflow customization via `.beads/PRIME.md`:

```bash
bd prime --export > .beads/PRIME.md  # Get default template
# Edit to customize (e.g., remove auto-commit/push for review-first workflow)
```

**Override order:**
1. Local `.beads/PRIME.md` (clone-specific)
2. Redirected location (if using shared beads)
3. Default built-in content

This provides workflow control without hacking agent files or CLAUDE.md. Consider how this interacts with the atomic commands approach - PRIME.md controls the session close protocol, while atomic commands control the execution steps.

**Possible integration:**
- PRIME.md could reference which atomic commands to run
- Or keep them separate: PRIME.md for high-level protocol, atomic commands for implementation

title: Allow skills/agents to specify custom audio events
description:
Skills and subagents should be able to specify custom audio events for their actions.

## Limitation
Claude Code hooks do NOT provide skill/subagent attribution. The payload only includes:
- `tool_name`, `tool_input`, `session_id`

There's no field indicating which skill or subagent triggered the tool.

## Possible Approaches

### 1. Infer from patterns (hacky)
Parse tool inputs to guess context:
- 'docs-seeker' likely uses WebFetch + specific patterns
- 'code-reviewer' uses Read + Grep patterns

### 2. Skill-side signaling
Skills could write to a known file or env var before invoking tools:
```bash
echo 'docs-seeker' > /tmp/tabz-current-skill
```
Then hook reads this file.

### 3. Request Claude Code feature
Ask Anthropic to add skill/agent context to hook payloads.

### 4. Custom audio via MCP
Skills could directly call TabzChrome audio MCP tools:
```
tabz_play_audio or tabz_speak
```

## Use Cases
- Research skills could have a 'searching' sound
- Build/test skills could have distinct completion sounds
- Different subagent types could have unique audio cues
close_reason: Removed - Claude Code hooks don't provide skill/agent context needed for this feature

- **Monitoring Dashboard**: htop | bottom | logs (3-pane split)
- **Dev Setup**: editor | terminal | lazygit
- **Claude Swarm**: 4-way split with multiple Claude workers

Profile stores: split layout, commands per pane, working directories.
Turns profiles from 'single terminal' into 'workspace templates'.

## Benefits
- Less React code to maintain
- Leverage existing battle-tested TUIs
- 'Done' state - TabzChrome becomes a terminal manager
- Any new feature = just spawn a TUI
- Simpler architecture
- Tmux already handles splits - minimal new code

## Questions to Consider
- What React features are essential vs nice-to-have?
- Can profile editing work as TUI?
- How would terminal grid layout work?
- Migration path from current dashboard?

title: bd-swarm --auto: fully autonomous backlog completion
description:
Add auto mode to bd-swarm that orchestrates the entire backlog to completion without user interaction.

## Concept
`/bd-swarm --auto` runs until backlog is empty:

1. **Wave N**: Spawn workers for ALL ready (unblocked) issues
   - Each worker gets a worktree
   - All run in parallel
2. **Monitor**: Watcher handles review â†’ docs â†’ merge â†’ push
3. **Check**: When wave completes, `bd ready` for newly unblocked
4. **Repeat**: Spawn Wave N+1 for new ready issues
5. **Context check**: If conductor hits 75%, /wipe with handoff
6. **Exit**: When `bd ready` returns empty â†’ 'Backlog complete\!'

## Auto Mode Differences
- **No AskUserQuestion** - autonomous decisions
- **Wave-based parallelization** - all unblocked run together
- **Self-healing** - /wipe + beads = full state recovery
- **Runs to completion** - not just one wave

## State Recovery After /wipe
Beads issues contain all state:
- Which issues are open/closed/in_progress
- Dependencies (what's blocked)
- Worktree locations (in issue comments or naming)

Handoff just needs:
```markdown
## Auto-Swarm in Progress
Wave 3 of backlog processing.
Run `/bd-swarm --auto` to continue.
```

## Decision Making (No User Questions)
| Decision | Auto Mode Choice |
|----------|------------------|
| How many workers? | All ready issues (up to 5) |
| Which skills? | Match from context |
| Review failed? | Nudge worker, wait |
| Worker stuck? | Kill after 10min, requeue issue |

## Example Run
```
$ claude '/bd-swarm --auto'

Wave 1: Spawning 3 workers (TabzChrome-abc, def, ghi)
...workers complete...
Merged, docs updated, pushed.

Wave 2: Spawning 2 workers (TabzChrome-jkl, mno) [were blocked by abc]
...workers complete...
Merged, docs updated, pushed.

Context at 78% - running /wipe...
[session clears, handoff sent]

Continuing auto-swarm...
Wave 3: Spawning 1 worker (TabzChrome-pqr)
...worker completes...

bd ready: no issues
Backlog complete\! 6 issues closed across 3 waves.
```

## Files
- plugins/conductor/commands/bd-swarm.md - add --auto flag handling
- plugins/conductor/agents/watcher.md - wave completion detection

title: Conductor: watcher orchestrates review â†’ docs â†’ merge pipeline
description:
When conductor:watcher monitors workers, it should orchestrate the full completion pipeline:

## Pipeline per Worker
1. Detect WORKER_DONE (worker committed + closed issue)
2. Spawn conductor:code-reviewer on the feature branch
3. If issues found â†’ nudge worker to fix, wait for re-commit
4. Mark worker as 'reviewed'

## Pipeline on ALL_DONE (all workers reviewed)
1. Merge all feature branches to main
2. Clean up worktrees
3. Spawn conductor:docs-updater to update CHANGELOG/API docs
4. bd sync && git push
5. Notify conductor 'Sprint complete'

## Files to Update
- `plugins/conductor/commands/bd-swarm.md` - auto-spawn watcher at end
- `plugins/conductor/agents/watcher.md` - add review + docs orchestration
- `plugins/conductor/agents/code-reviewer.md` - ensure structured results for watcher
